<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">625,000</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The benefit payable
under the SERP is a lifetime annuity equal to 2% of the participant&#146;s average base salary for the last three full calendar years of employment multiplied by the participant&#146;s years of service (up to a maximum of 25 years). Payments to
vested participants commence after termination of employment and upon the earlier of (i)&nbsp;the attainment of age 65 or (ii)&nbsp;the request of the participant at any time after the attainment of age 55 (in which case the annual amount is reduced
by 5%&nbsp;per year for each year it is paid before the participant&#146;s attainment of age 65). Participants become vested under the SERP upon the earliest of (a)&nbsp;the completion of 10 years of service, (b)&nbsp;the attainment of age 40 and
completion of five years of service or (c)&nbsp;the attainment of age 65; provided, however, that TH USA may from time to time in its sole discretion determine that participants become vested at such earlier time as TH USA by action of the Board of
Directors so determines; provided that a participant who is terminated for &#147;cause&#148; (as defined in the SERP) will forfeit all rights to the SERP benefit (whether or not vested). Payments under the SERP are subject to any applicable Social
Security or other taxes required to be withheld by law. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">53 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On October&nbsp;22, 2004, the President signed the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (the
&#147;AJCA&#148;), which changes the tax laws governing the operation of deferred compensation plans such as the SERP. Although the AJCA imposes numerous requirements on deferred compensation plans, these new requirements do not apply to benefits
accrued and vested as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 (unless the plan is &#147;materially modified&#148; thereafter). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In order to preserve the favorable tax treatment with respect to grandfathered SERP benefits and to ensure the SERP is not materially modified, the
Company recently proposed amendments to the SERP that &#147;froze&#148; the SERP effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. This means that, effective as of January&nbsp;1, 2005, participants will no longer earn or accrue any additional benefits under
the SERP and any future salary increases will not be taken into account under the SERP benefit formula. This freezing of the SERP in no way impacts or reduces the SERP benefit accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2004. Participants will be entitled to
receive a distribution of their SERP benefit accrued as of December&nbsp;31, 2004 at such time or times a distribution is permitted under the terms of the SERP in effect prior to 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For purposes of the SERP, the amount specified in the Annual Compensation portion of the Summary Compensation Table under
the heading &#147;Salary&#148; would constitute &#147;base salary.&#148; As of March&nbsp;31, 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Newman completed 12 years of service and was vested under the SERP. Mr.&nbsp;Newman currently receives monthly payments under the SERP in
the amount of $16,200. Mr.&nbsp;Dyer was scheduled to become vested under the SERP in August 2006 (following three years of service to TH USA). However, owing to the freeze of the SERP described above, Mr.&nbsp;Dyer will not accrue any benefit under
this program. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Certain Employment Agreements </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company (including its subsidiaries) had employment agreements with
Messrs. Hilfiger, Horowitz, Dyer and Newman during the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005. The Company (including its subsidiaries) had letter agreements with Messrs. Rosenblatt and Killion during the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Thomas J. Hilfiger</U> </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger, the Company&#146;s Honorary
Chairman of the Board and Principal Designer, provides for his employment as the designer of all products carrying the Tommy Hilfiger trademarks until his death, disability or incompetence. Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger receives an annual base salary of
$900,000, subject to adjustments. If net sales (as defined in the agreement) of TH USA and its subsidiaries are less than $48,333,333 in any year, Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger&#146;s base salary for such year is reduced by 1.5% of such shortfall, to not less
than $500,000. If net sales are greater than $48,333,333 in any fiscal year, Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger receives an additional payment equal to 1.5% of such excess. If Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger terminates his employment without the consent of TH USA other than by
reason of his death, disability or incompetence, TH USA will have no further obligations under the agreement. The agreement provides that TH USA and its subsidiaries cannot enter into any line of business without the consent of Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger if
he shall reasonably determine that such line of business would be detrimental to the Tommy Hilfiger trademarks. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Joel J. Horowitz</U> </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As previously announced, effective as of the close of business on October 31, 2005, Mr. Horowitz retired as a Director and Non-Executive Chairman of the
Board of Directors. On April&nbsp;1, 2004, the Company and TH USA entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz (the &#147;FY 2005 Agreement&#148;). Under this agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz served as the Executive Chairman of the
Company and TH USA for a term ending March&nbsp;31, 2005. Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz&#146;s agreement provided for him to receive base salary of $1,000,000 for the fiscal year ending March&nbsp;31, 2005. He is also eligible for an annual cash bonus based
upon achieving specified revenue and net income goals, with a target bonus of 100% of his base salary and a maximum bonus of 200% of his base salary. Under this agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz is not entitled to receive any stock options, restricted
stock or other long term incentive compensation. If the Company terminated Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz&#146;s employment without cause or he resigned for good reason, he would be entitled to a lump sum payment of his base salary through the term of the
</FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">54 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">agreement, plus any payment of his bonus for the fiscal year ending March&nbsp;31, 2005 based on actual performance for the year. Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz has
agreed in his employment agreement to abide by covenants regarding Company ownership of his work product, confidentiality of Company information, non-competition, and non-solicitation of Company employees, and to cooperate with the Company and its
affiliates after termination of his employment in litigations and governmental investigations. The FY 2005 Agreement expired on March&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">From April 1, 2005 to October 31, 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz served as the Non-Executive Chairman of the Board of the Company. In consideration for his
services as Non-Executive Chairman of the Board, the Company paid Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz at a rate of $40,000 per year, plus benefits. Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz also received $5,000 for attendance at each meeting of the Board of Directors of the Company during
such period. Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz retired from the Company at the Board of Directors&#146; meeting held on October&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prior to entering into the FY 2005 Agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz had an employment agreement which originally provided for his employment as Chief
Executive Officer of TH USA until March&nbsp;31, 2004, and which was revised upon the appointment of Mr.&nbsp;Dyer in August 2003 to provide for Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz&#146;s employment as Executive Chairman of the Company and TH USA. The agreement
provided for an annual base salary, which in fiscal 2004 was $676,595, with increases from the prior year by the average percentage increase for all employees of TH USA. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company is subject to Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (&#147;Section
162&nbsp;(m)&#148;), under which public companies are not permitted to deduct for federal income tax purposes annual compensation paid to certain executive officers in excess of $1,000,000 per executive, unless such excess is paid pursuant to an
arrangement based upon performance and approved by shareholders and provided that the other requirements set forth in Section&nbsp;162 (m)&nbsp;and related regulations are met. Payments required to be made pursuant to the aforementioned employment
agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger, which was entered into prior to the effective date of Section&nbsp;162(m), are not subject to such restrictions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;6, 1998, the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee approved and the Board of Directors adopted, and on November&nbsp;2, 1998, the
shareholders approved, the renewal of the Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A., Inc. Supplemental Executive Incentive Compensation Plan (the &#147;SEIC Plan&#148;), which was scheduled to terminate on April&nbsp;1, 1999, for each of the five fiscal years in the
period ending March&nbsp;31, 2004. The purpose of the SEIC Plan was to provide a significant and flexible economic opportunity to Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz, in an effort to reward his contribution to the Company and its subsidiaries. The SEIC Plan was
administered by the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee and provided for a cash award to Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz equal to 5% of the Company&#146;s consolidated earnings before depreciation, interest on financing of fixed assets, non-operating expenses
and taxes (&#147;operating earnings&#148;). Awards under the plan were calculated and paid quarterly based on 3.75% of operating earnings for the first three fiscal quarters, with the remaining amount of the bonus (based on the 5% rate) paid at the
end of the fiscal year. The amount of the award was reduced by the amount of any other bonuses paid or payable under any employment or bonus agreement between the Company or TH USA and Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz. The SEIC Plan did not contain any cap on the
maximum amount of the bonus payable thereunder. While the Company believes that compensation payable pursuant to the SEIC Plan will be deductible for federal income tax purposes pursuant to Section&nbsp;162(m), there can be no assurance in this
regard. The SEIC Plan expired on March&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger, and Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz&#146;s prior employment agreement, also provide that such executives are eligible to receive additional annual bonuses at the discretion of TH USA&#146;s Board of Directors or
Compensation Committee. If, however, compensation is awarded based on an arrangement that does not satisfy the requirements of Section&nbsp;162(m), the Company would not be allowed to deduct for tax purposes any payments in excess of the $1,000,000
limitation. No discretionary bonuses were paid to these executives with respect to the Company&#146;s last three fiscal years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On June&nbsp;29, 2001, the Company and Tommy Hilfiger (Eastern Hemisphere) Limited, a subsidiary of the Company (&#147;THEH&#148;) entered into a stock
purchase agreement (the &#147;Stock Purchase Agreement&#148;) with TH Europe </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">55 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Holdings Limited, a subsidiary of AIHL (&#147;TH Europe Holdings&#148;), pursuant to which THEH agreed to acquire from TH Europe Holdings all of the issued
and outstanding shares of capital stock of TH International N.V. (&#147;THNV&#148;), the owner of Tommy Hilfiger Europe B.V. (&#147;TH Europe&#148;), the Company&#146;s European licensee, for a cash purchase price of $200,000,000 plus acquisition
related costs of $6,789,000 and assumed debt of $42,629,000. Also on June&nbsp;29, 2001, AIHL executed a guarantee of the performance by TH Europe Holdings of its obligations under the Stock Purchase Agreement. The TH Europe Acquisition was
completed on July&nbsp;5, 2001. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Messrs. Hilfiger and Horowitz
have agreed to waive any additional compensation attributable to the net sales and operating earnings of the Company&#146;s acquired European licensee to which they might otherwise be contractually entitled under their existing (and in
Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz&#146;s case, his prior) employment arrangements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I><U>David F. Dyer</U> </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;3, 2003,
the Company and TH USA entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Dyer for him to serve as Chief Executive Officer and President of the Company and TH USA for an initial term ending March&nbsp;31, 2007. Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s agreement
provides for him to receive a base salary of at least $1,250,000 per year, with annual increases at least equal to the average annual base salary increases provided TH USA&#146;s corporate employees generally in the annual review process. He is also
eligible for an annual cash bonus based upon achieving specified revenue and net income goals, with a target bonus of 100% of his base salary and a maximum bonus of 200% of his base salary. He also received a cash signing bonus of $1,000,000.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Dyer was granted an option to purchase 500,000
ordinary shares under the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation 2001 Stock Incentive Plan on the effective date of his agreement. The Company has also agreed to make additional 500,000 share option grants on April&nbsp;1, 2004 and April&nbsp;1, 2005 (subject
to adjustment in the event of any stock splits or other changes in capitalization or corporate transactions). Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s option grants will vest in three equal annual installments. However, upon a change of control of the Company, the
options will vest on an accelerated basis and will remain exercisable for their full remaining terms notwithstanding any subsequent termination of his employment other than for cause. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If the Company terminated Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s employment without cause or he resigns for good reason, he would be entitled
to be paid cash severance equal to his annual base salary plus his target annual bonus, times a multiplier that varies depending on the circumstances, as explained below. He would also be paid a pro-rata annual bonus for the fiscal year of
termination, based on actual performance for the year. If a termination of employment were to occur in anticipation of, or within the period of 24 months following, a change of control, he would receive a lump sum severance payment with a multiplier
of three. In all other cases, the multiplier would be two, and the cash severance would be paid as salary continuation over 24 months. In addition, if Mr.&nbsp;Dyer resigned voluntarily without good reason during the 30-day period beginning on the
first anniversary of a change of control, he would be entitled to a lump sum severance benefit, with a multiplier of one. The employment agreement provides that Mr.&nbsp;Dyer will be reimbursed for legal fees incurred in connection with entering
into his employment agreement and for any federal excise taxes imposed on payments that are contingent on a change of control. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Dyer has agreed in his employment agreement to abide by covenants regarding Company ownership of his work product, confidentiality of Company
information, non-competition, and non-solicitation of Company employees, and to cooperate with the Company and its affiliates after termination of his employment in litigations and governmental investigations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;10, 2005, the Company, TH USA and Mr.&nbsp;Dyer entered into
an agreement, at Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s initiative, that waives certain bonus payments and salary increases he would otherwise have been contractually entitled to receive under his August 2003 employment agreement. Mr.&nbsp;Dyer had initiated
discussions with the Compensation Committee of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors last year about his request for these waivers in order to better align with the Company&#146;s employee compensation structure in view of what he believed was good
management practice at a time of corporate repositioning. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">56 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">To that end, under the terms of the waiver, Mr.&nbsp;Dyer (i)&nbsp;acknowledges his waiver of $125,000 of
his bonus for the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 that he was otherwise entitled to receive under the employment agreement so that his bonus payout aligned and was consistent with the percentage of target payouts of other employees of the
Company; (ii)&nbsp;acknowledges his waiver of the $37,500 increase in his annual base salary that was to have taken effect pursuant to his employment agreement beginning on October&nbsp;1, 2004; and (iii)&nbsp;waives the additional $51,500 increase
in his annual base salary that would otherwise take effect pursuant to his employment agreement on October&nbsp;1, 2005, which was not, in fact, waived. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Dyer, in his sole discretion, may waive the increase in his base salary
that will be due on October&nbsp;1, 2006 as well as portions of any bonus for the fiscal years ending March&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2007 that may be payable under the bonus calculation formula in his employment agreement. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The waiver stipulates that the waived amounts will not be repaid, with the
only exception being if Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s employment were to be terminated by the Company prior to the March&nbsp;31, 2007 term of his employment agreement without cause or by Mr.&nbsp;Dyer for good reason (as such terms are defined in his
employment agreement). However, in no event will the waived amounts be paid if Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s employment is terminated following or in connection with a change of control (as defined in the employment agreement). Solely for purposes of
calculation the amount of any severance payments payable to Mr.&nbsp;Dyer under the employment agreement following termination of his employment, he will be treated as if his annual base salary rate were the amount that would have been payable to
him under the employment agreement in the absence of his waivers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I><U>Robert Rosenblatt</U> </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;4,
2004, TH USA entered into a letter agreement with Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt, providing for his employment as Group President and Chief Operating Officer of TH USA and Chief Operating Officer of the Company. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Under the terms of the letter agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt will receive an
annual base salary of $750,000, subject to annual review, and will be eligible to participate in the Company&#146;s Incentive Compensation Plan beginning in fiscal 2006, with incentive levels set at 100% of his base salary. Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt will
participate in all benefit plans and programs the Company provides to all employees in accordance with their terms and conditions as they may be modified by the Company from time to time. The letter agreement further provides that
Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt will be reimbursed for up to seven months of temporary housing (up to $50,000) and reasonable relocation expenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt also received a signing bonus of $350,000 in connection with the execution of the letter agreement. In the event that
Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt resigns or his employment is terminated by the Company for cause (as defined in the letter agreement) within the first year of his employment with the Company, he is required to repay the Company within 30 days of his resignation
or termination a proportionate amount of such signing bonus. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">On the date of execution of his letter agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt was granted 225,000 options to purchase shares of the Company&#146;s ordinary stock subject to the terms and conditions of the Company&#146;s 2003 Incentive Compensation
Plan (the &#147;2003 Plan&#148;) and 25,000 shares of restricted stock subject to the terms and conditions of the Company&#146;s 2001 Stock Incentive Plan. In addition, pursuant to the terms of the letter agreement, on each of April&nbsp;1, 2005 and
April&nbsp;1, 2006, Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt will be granted either (a)&nbsp;175,000 stock options or (b)&nbsp;at the discretion of the Company, such other award other than stock options (including, but not limited to, cash, stock appreciation rights,
restricted stock or restricted stock units) comparable in value to the grant of 175,000 stock options. On April&nbsp;1, 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt was granted 175,000 stock options. Any stock options granted pursuant to the letter agreement will have
an exercise price equal to the Fair Market Value (as defined in the 2003 Plan) of the Company&#146;s ordinary shares on the grant date. Each stock option grant under the letter agreement will vest 25%, 25% and 50%, respectively, on each of the first
three anniversaries of the grant date for each grant. The restricted stock granted under the letter agreement shall vest in full on the third anniversary of the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">57 </FONT></P>

<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">letter agreement. In the event of a Change in Control (as defined in the 2003 Plan), all outstanding stock options, restricted stock or other such stock
awards granted to Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt under the letter agreement shall become fully vested and exercisable. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt is terminated for any reason other than his death, disability, resignation or Cause (as defined in the letter agreement), and if
Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt executes a release and separation agreement satisfactory to the Company, Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt will receive base salary continuation for 12 months from the date his employment terminates. Such salary continuation will be offset by
any compensation and benefits Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt is entitled to receive from other employment (including self employment) during the salary continuation period. Following such termination, Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt will not be entitled to any bonus not
already paid or any other benefits provided by the letter agreement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Rosenblatt has agreed in his employment agreement to abide by covenants regarding confidentiality of Company information, non-competition, and non-solicitation of Company employees. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Joel H. Newman</U> </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Newman retired from the Company in November 2004. The employment
agreement, as amended, with Mr.&nbsp;Newman, the Company&#146;s former Executive Vice President&#151;Finance and Operations, provided for his employment with TH USA until March&nbsp;31, 2005, provided, however, that Mr.&nbsp;Newman had the right to
terminate his employment voluntarily before March&nbsp;31, 2005 on at least 60 days&#146; advance notice to TH USA provided that the date of termination is after November&nbsp;30, 2004 (an &#147;Elective Termination&#148;). The agreement provided
for an annual base salary of $950,000 in fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2005. Under the agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Newman was entitled to receive a minimum bonus of $634,000 in fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2005; provided that if the Company achieves or exceeds its
annual budget for a specified fiscal year, the minimum bonus will be 100% of the base salary for such year. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If Mr.&nbsp;Newman&#146;s employment was terminated by the Company without &#147;cause&#148; (as defined in the agreement) or by Mr.&nbsp;Newman with
&#147;good reason&#148; (as defined in the agreement), or when the agreement terminates on March&nbsp;31, 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Newman would have generally, subject to certain conditions, be entitled to receive (i)&nbsp;base salary continuation until the
end of the then current term plus one year (subject to mitigation from compensation and benefits received from other employment (the &#147;Mitigation&#148;)), (ii)&nbsp;any unpaid bonus for a fiscal year that ended on or before the date of
termination, (iii)&nbsp;for a termination occurring on March&nbsp;31, 2005, his full bonus for the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, and (iv)&nbsp;for a termination occurring after March&nbsp;31, 2004, but before March&nbsp;31, 2005, a
pro-rated annual bonus for the fiscal year in which the termination occurs. If Mr.&nbsp;Newman elected to terminate his employment before March&nbsp;31, 2005 on 60 days notice, he was entitled to receive any unpaid bonus for a fiscal year that has
ended and, subject to certain conditions, base salary continuation for the one-year period beginning on the date of termination, plus a pro-rated portion of his annual bonus (if any) that otherwise would have been payable to Mr.&nbsp;Newman in
respect of the fiscal year in which the date of termination occurs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">In addition, if Mr.&nbsp;Newman&#146;s employment was terminated during calendar year 2004 by the Company without cause or by Mr.&nbsp;Newman with good reason or if there is an Elective Termination, he would have received a full year&#146;s
credited service for 2004 under the SERP. Finally, if Mr.&nbsp;Newman&#146;s employment was terminated by the Company without cause or by Mr.&nbsp;Newman with good reason within two years after a change of control, his salary continuation payments
would not be subject to the Mitigation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Newman has
agreed in his employment agreement and his separation agreement to abide by covenants regarding confidentiality of Company information, non-competition, and non-solicitation of Company employees. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Theo Killion</U> </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;26, 2004, TH USA entered into a letter agreement with
Mr.&nbsp;Killion, providing for his employment as Executive Vice President&#151;Human Resources of TH USA. In January 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Killion was appointed as Executive Vice President&#151;Human Resources of the Company. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">58 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Under the terms of the letter agreement, Mr.&nbsp;Killion will receive an annual base salary of $475,000,
subject to annual increases not to exceed the average increase of salaried employees for TH USA. During fiscal year 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Killion&#146;s base salary was increased to $500,000. Mr.&nbsp;Killion is eligible to participate in the
Company&#146;s Incentive Compensation Plan, with incentive levels set at 75% of his base salary and a maximum of 200%. Mr.&nbsp;Killion will participate in all benefit plans and programs the Company provides to all employees and those in a similar
executive capacity, in accordance with their terms and conditions as they may be modified by the Company from time to time. The letter agreement further provides that Mr.&nbsp;Killion will be reimbursed for all usual and customary moving and
relocation expenses, including up to 120 days of temporary housing. Mr.&nbsp;Killion also received a signing bonus of $175,000 in connection with the execution of the letter agreement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pursuant to the letter agreement, on March&nbsp;30, 2004, Mr.&nbsp;Killion was granted 100,000 options to purchase shares of
the Company&#146;s ordinary stock subject to the terms and conditions of the 2003 Plan. In addition, pursuant to the terms of the letter agreement, on March&nbsp;31, 2005, Mr.&nbsp;Killion was granted 50,000 stock options. Stock options granted
pursuant to the letter agreement have an exercise price equal to the Fair Market Value (as defined in the 2003 Plan) of the Company&#146;s ordinary shares on the grant date. Each stock option grant under the letter agreement will vest 25%, 25% and
50%, respectively, on each of the first three anniversaries of the grant date for each grant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If Mr.&nbsp;Killion is terminated without Cause (as defined in the 2003 Plan) or there is a Change in Control (as defined in the 2003 Plan), and if Mr.&nbsp;Killion executes a release and separation agreement
satisfactory to the Company, Mr.&nbsp;Killion will receive (i)&nbsp;base salary continuation for 12 months from the date his employment terminates; (ii)&nbsp;his earned bonus (according to the Company&#146;s plan and performance); and
(iii)&nbsp;reimbursement for the cost of his COBRA coverage (provided he elects for COBRA). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Killion has agreed in his employment agreement to abide by covenants regarding confidentiality of Company information, non-competition, and non-solicitation of Company employees. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:2%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I><U>Performance Awards</U> </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As described above, the Company is subject to Section&nbsp;162(m), under
which public companies are not permitted to deduct for federal income tax purposes annual compensation paid to certain executive officers in excess of $1,000,000 per executive, unless such excess is paid pursuant to an arrangement based upon
performance and approved by shareholders and provided that the other requirements set forth in Section&nbsp;162 (m)&nbsp;and related regulations are met. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;16, 2003, the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee approved and the Board of Directors adopted, and on November&nbsp;3, 2003, the
shareholders of the Company approved, the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation 2003 Incentive Compensation Plan (the &#147;2003 Plan&#148;). The purpose of the 2003 Plan is to enable the Company and its subsidiaries to continue to attract, retain and motivate
officers, employees and non-employee directors by providing incentives directly linked to the profitability of the Company&#146;s businesses and increases in shareholder value by providing the Company with the ability to grant stock options and
stock appreciation rights to employees, to pay performance-based annual bonuses to employees, and to make automatic grants of stock options to non-employee directors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As explained above, Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s employment agreement provides for annual bonuses. The annual bonuses for the fiscal
year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and subsequent fiscal years will be payable under the 2003 Plan. Generally, under Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s employment agreement, his annual bonus is payable only if minimum goals for net revenue and income before taxes of
the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries for the fiscal year as compared to the budgeted amount approved by the Company&#146;s Board of Directors are met. Assuming that the applicable minimum goals for a fiscal year are met, the annual bonus
will equal a percentage of Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s base salary for the year, ranging between 25% and 200%, based upon the achievement of income before taxes and, for the fiscal years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, and March&nbsp;31, 2005, only, the
achievement of net revenue, in each case as compared to the budgeted amount. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">59 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each bonus under the 2003 Plan other than those provided for under Mr.&nbsp;Dyer&#146;s employment
agreement, as described above, will be conditioned upon the attainment of pre-established performance goals measured over a performance period designated by the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee. A performance period may be one or more periods
of time over which the attainment of one or more performance goals will be measured for the purposes of determining a participant&#146;s right to payment in respect of a bonus under the 2003 Plan. The performance goals applicable to a performance
period must be established in writing by the Compensation Committee no later than the earlier of (i)&nbsp;90 days after the start of the performance period or (ii)&nbsp;the date upon which 25% of the performance period has elapsed. The performance
goals will be determined by reference to one or more of the following performance measures, as selected by the Compensation Committee and as applicable to the Company or any of its subsidiaries, or any of their respective divisions or business
units: net revenues; gross profit; income before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization; income from operations; income before taxes; net income; basic or diluted earnings per share; reduction of debt or similar obligations; unit volume;
change in working capital; Company stock price; return on capital; and return on investment; each as determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles as consistently applied by the Company, and if so determined by the
Compensation Committee, adjusted to omit the effects of extraordinary items of gain or loss on the disposal of a business segment, unusual or infrequently occurring events and transactions and cumulative effects of changes in accounting principles;
provided that such an adjustment may only be made if the Compensation Committee has so provided before the end of the period described above for establishing performance goals, and then only to the extent permitted under Section&nbsp;162(m) of the
Internal Revenue Code. Performance measures may vary from performance period to performance period and from participant to participant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Generally, a participant may receive a bonus only to the extent that the Compensation Committee certifies that the applicable performance goals have been
achieved. The Compensation Committee has the discretion to reduce or eliminate, but cannot increase, any amounts otherwise payable in respect of bonuses under the 2003 Plan. In addition, in order to receive a bonus, a participant will be required to
remain employed by the Company or one of its subsidiaries on the date of payment, unless otherwise provided in the applicable award schedule. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Any bonuses that are paid will be paid in the form of cash, Ordinary Shares, or a combination thereof, as the Committee may determine in its sole
discretion, except to the extent otherwise provided in the applicable award schedule. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Awards under the 2003 Plan to officers and employees in the form of non-qualified stock options, incentive stock options, stock appreciation rights and bonuses are intended to qualify as &#147;performance based
compensation&#148; under Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. Currently, the bonuses for Messrs. Horowitz and Newman for fiscal 2005 are based on the requirements of the 2003 Plan. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Indemnification Agreements </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Under the law of the British Virgin Islands (&#147;BVI&#148;), where the
Company is incorporated, and the law of Delaware, where the Company&#146;s principal U.S. subsidiary, TH USA is incorporated, a corporation has the power to provide mandatory&nbsp;indemnification against certain liabilities and expenses incurred by
its officers and directors if they meet the applicable statutory standard of conduct. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the case of officers and directors of TH USA, TH USA&#146;s by-laws, as permitted by Delaware law, provide that TH USA shall indemnify any person who is or was a party or threatened to be a party to any threatened,
pending or completed proceedings&nbsp;by reason of the fact that the person is or was a director or officer of TH USA, if such person acted in good faith and in a manner&nbsp;he or she reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best
interests of TH USA.&nbsp;TH USA&#146;s by-laws also require TH USA to&nbsp;advance expenses incurred in defending or investigating a threatened or pending proceeding upon receipt by TH USA of an undertaking by the director or officer to repay such
amount if it is ultimately determined that such person is not entitled to be indemnified. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the case of officers and directors of the Company, the Company&#146;s Articles of Association permit the Company to indemnify any person who is or was a party or threatened to be made a party to any threatened,
</FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">60 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">pending or completed proceedings by reason of the fact that the person is or was a director or officer of the Company, if such person acted honestly and in
good faith with a view to the best interests of the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;31, 2005, as permitted by BVI law, the Company began entering into indemnification agreements with its current officers and directors, including Messrs. Horowitz, Hilfiger, Dyer, Rosenblatt and Killion, following the prior
authorization of such agreements by the unanimous vote of the Company&#146;s independent directors. These indemnification agreements provide mandatory indemnification and advancement of expenses for the Company&#146;s current officers and directors,
subject to meeting the applicable standard of conduct under BVI law, that is generally comparable to the mandatory indemnification and advancement of expenses provided to TH USA&#146;s officers and directors under TH USA&#146;s by-laws. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The indemnification agreements require the Company to indemnify its
officers and directors to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law if, by reason of their serving or having served as officers or directors of the Company or, at the request of the Company, in any capacity at another entity, they are made or
threatened to be made a party to or a participant in any proceeding, against costs and expenses, including reasonable attorneys&#146; fees, and any losses, judgments or amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred in connection with
such proceeding, if the officer or director acted honestly and in good faith with a view to the best interests of the Company. The indemnification agreements also require&nbsp;the Company to pay in advance of the final disposition of a proceeding
all reasonable expenses, including reasonable attorneys&#146; fees, incurred in connection with such proceeding, subject to an undertaking by the officer or director to repay any advance if it is ultimately determined that the officer or director is
not entitled to be indemnified against such expenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
rights under the indemnification agreement to receive indemnification and advancement of expenses are not exclusive of any other rights that the director or officer may have under applicable law, the Company&#146;s Articles of Association, a vote of
stockholders or a resolution of directors, director and officer liability insurance policies or otherwise. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company is not required by the indemnification agreements to indemnify the directors and officers against fines and penalties or with respect to
claims (i)&nbsp;for an accounting of profits made from the purchase or sale of the Company&#146;s securities under Section&nbsp;16 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, (ii)&nbsp;resulting from the person&#146;s knowingly fraudulent, dishonest or
willful misconduct, or (iii)&nbsp;for which the payment of expenses or losses under the indemnification agreement is not permitted by applicable law. The indemnification agreements require the officer or director (i)&nbsp;to cooperate fully with the
Company in responding to any proceeding, (ii)&nbsp;to provide all required information and documents, and (iii)&nbsp;to be available for testimony, in each case as reasonably requested by the Company. A determination regarding a person&#146;s
entitlement to indemnification may be made by either independent counsel selected by the Board of Directors of the Company or by the disinterested directors of the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The indemnification agreements also provide that the Company shall use its best efforts to continue to maintain
directors&#146; and&nbsp;officers&#146; liability insurance policies for the benefit of the persons executing the indemnification agreements having at least the same liability coverage amounts as the Company&#146;s current directors&#146; and
officers&#146; liability insurance policies; provided that the Company is not obligated to pay premiums for such insurance that are, in the good faith determination of the Board of Directors&nbsp;of the Company, unreasonable for the Company to
undertake. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Stock-Based Plans </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Employee Stock Incentive Plans. </I>At the Company&#146;s 2003 annual
meeting, the shareholders approved the 2003 Plan, which was subsequently amended in February 2004. The purpose of the 2003 Plan is to enable the Company and its subsidiaries to continue to attract, retain and motivate officers, employees and
non-employee directors by providing incentives directly linked to the profitability of the Company&#146;s businesses and increases in </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">61 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">shareholder value by providing the Company with the ability to grant stock options and stock appreciation rights to employees, to pay performance-based
annual bonuses to employees, and to make automatic grants of stock options to non-employee directors. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Currently, the Company grants options under the 2003 Plan and under the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation 2001 Stock Incentive Plan (the &#147;2001 Stock
Incentive Plan&#148;), which was approved by the Company&#146;s shareholders at the Company&#146;s 2001 annual meeting. Following such approval, no further grants may be made under the Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A. and Tommy Hilfiger (Eastern Hemisphere)
Limited 1992 Stock Incentive Plans (the &#147;1992 Stock Incentive Plans&#148;; and together with the 2001 Stock Incentive Plan and the 2003 Plan, the &#147;Employee Stock Incentive Plans&#148;). Grants previously made under the 1992 Stock Incentive
Plans remain outstanding in accordance with their terms. The Company expects to continue to make grants under its 2001 Stock Incentive Plan while Ordinary Shares remain available thereunder. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 2001 Stock Incentive Plan authorizes the grant of stock options, stock
appreciation rights related to stock options and restricted stock to officers, employees and directors of the Company and its subsidiaries with respect to up to 3,500,000 Ordinary Shares (subject to certain adjustments as provided in the plan);
provided that no more than 350,000 of those shares may be awarded pursuant to grants of restricted stock. No participant under the 2001 Stock Incentive Plan may be granted awards covering in excess of 700,000 Ordinary Shares in any fiscal year of
the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 2001 Stock Incentive Plan is administered by
the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee. Awards under the plan are subject to such terms and conditions as may be determined by the Compensation Committee and specified in the applicable award agreement; provided that any stock option or related
stock appreciation right must have an exercise price of not less than fair market value at, and may not be exercisable more than 10 years after, the date of grant. An award agreement may provide for acceleration or immediate vesting in the event of
a change of control of the Company or any of its subsidiaries. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Mr. Hilfiger is not eligible for grants under the 2001 Stock Incentive Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 2003 Plan authorizes the grant of stock options and stock appreciation rights related to stock options to officers, employees and non-employee directors of the Company and its subsidiaries with respect to up to
3,500,000 Ordinary Shares (subject to certain adjustments as provided in the plan). No participant under the 2003 Plan may be granted awards covering in excess of 700,000 Ordinary Shares in any fiscal year of the Company. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 2003 Plan is administered by the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee.
Awards under the plan are subject to such terms and conditions as may be determined by the Compensation Committee and specified in the applicable award agreement; provided that any stock option or related stock appreciation right must have an
exercise price of not less than fair market value at, and may not be exercisable more than 10 years after, the date of grant. Under the 2003 Plan, in the event of a change of control of the Company, unless otherwise provided in the applicable award
agreement or another agreement with a particular participant, unvested stock options and stock appreciation rights will vest in full and, if the participant&#146;s employment terminates, other than for cause, within two years following the change of
control, his or her vested stock options and stock appreciation rights will remain exercisable for at least two years or, if shorter, the remainder of their original terms. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr. Hilfiger is eligible for grants under the 2003 Plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Currently, over half of the full-time employees of the Company and its subsidiaries are participants in the Employee Stock
Incentive Plans. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Directors Option Plan</I>. In August 1994,
the shareholders of the Company approved the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation Non-Employee Directors Stock Option Plan, which was amended in February 2004 (the &#147;Directors </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">62 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Option Plan&#148;). Options for up to 400,000 Ordinary Shares (subject to certain adjustments as provided in the plan) may be granted under the Directors
Option Plan. Each director who is not an officer or employee of the Company or any subsidiary of the Company (a &#147;Non-Employee Director&#148;) receives an initial stock option to purchase 20,000 Ordinary Shares, and subsequent annual grants of
options to purchase 4,000 Ordinary Shares (the &#147;Annual Option Grant&#148;), in each case at an exercise price equal to the fair market value at the date of grant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Directors Option Plan is administered by the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee. However, grants of stock options to
participants under the Directors Option Plan and the amount, nature and timing of the grants are not subject to the determination of such committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The term of each stock option granted under the Directors Option Plan is 10 years unless earlier terminated by termination of the director status of a
Non-Employee Director, and the stock options granted prior to February&nbsp;2, 2004, are exercisable in equal installments over five years from the date of grant. Grants made under the Directors Option Plan on or after February&nbsp;2, 2004, are
fully exercisable on the anniversary of the date of grant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
Directors Option Plan expired on December&nbsp;31, 2004. Following the expiration of the Directors Option Plan, stock options will be granted to Non-Employee Directors under the 2003 Plan. Under the 2003 Plan, each Non-Employee Director receives an
initial stock option to purchase 20,000 Ordinary Shares, and subsequent annual grants of options to purchase 4,000 Ordinary Shares, in each case at an exercise price equal to the fair market value at the date of grant. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The 2003 Plan is administered by the Company&#146;s Compensation Committee.
However, grants of stock options to Non-Employee Directors under the 2003 Plan and the amount, nature and timing of the grants are not subject to the determination of such committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The term of each stock option granted under the 2003 Plan is 10 years unless earlier terminated by termination of the
director status of a Non-Employee Director, and the stock options granted are fully exercisable on the anniversary of the date of grant. The 2003 Plan expires in December&nbsp;31, 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Compensation Committee Interlocks and Insider Participation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s Compensation Committee consists of Ms.&nbsp;DeVard, who is the Chair, Mr.&nbsp;Baeza and Mr.&nbsp;Sze.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">AIHL-Pepe Limited, a BVI corporation (collectively with its
predecessors and certain of its affiliates, &#147;AIHL&#148;), is owned 22.5% by Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger, Honorary Chairman of the Board, Principal Designer and a Director of the Company, and 7.5% by Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz, formerly Non-Executive Chairman of
the Board and a Director of the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During the
Company&#146;s last fiscal year, Messrs. Hilfiger and Horowitz were executive officers and/or directors of AIHL (which has no Compensation Committee). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See &#147;Certain Relationships and Related Transactions.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

2003 Incentive Compensation Plan, and the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation Non-Employee Directors Stock Option Plan. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc89342_19"></A>ITEM&nbsp;13. CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Certain relationships and transactions between the Company and certain directors and executive officers of the Company and certain of their affiliates are described below. See &#147;Executive
Compensation&#151;Compensation Committee Interlocks and Insider Participation&#148; for a complete description of the interests and relationships of such directors and executive officers in and with these affiliates. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">THLI is party to a geographic license agreement for Japan with Tommy Hilfiger
Japan Corporation (&#147;THJC&#148;). Messrs. Hilfiger and Horowitz indirectly own a minority equity interest in THJC. Under the license agreement, THJC pays THLI a royalty based on a percentage of the value of licensed products sold by it. Subject
to certain exceptions, all products sold by or through THJC must be purchased through THEH or TH USA pursuant to buying agency agreements. Under these agreements, THEH and TH USA are paid a buying agency commission based on a percentage of the cost
of products sourced through them. Pursuant to these arrangements, royalties and buying agency commissions totaled $6,310,000 during fiscal 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Messrs. Hilfiger and Horowitz indirectly hold a minority equity interest in Pepe Jeans SL, which serves as TH Europe&#146;s sales and collection agent in
Spain. In fiscal 2005, commissions and fees paid by TH Europe pursuant to these arrangements totaled $11,184,000. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pursuant to the indemnification provisions of the applicable Articles of Association and by-laws of the Company and its subsidiaries, as well as
indemnification agreements entered into between THC and its officers and directors, the Company has been paying the legal fees and expenses of certain officers and directors of the </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">65 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Company and its subsidiaries that are incurred in connection with the USAO investigation and related class action lawsuits, subject to undertakings by the
individuals to reimburse such amounts in the event it is ultimately determined that they are not entitled to indemnification. The following is a list of the Company&#146;s directors and officers that have received advancement of their legal fees in
excess of $60,000 for the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and the amount advanced as of such date: (i)&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Hilfiger: $150,220; (ii)&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Horowitz: $115,387; (iii)&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Dyer: $161,008; (iv)&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Scirocco: $
243,216. As a condition to the payment by TH USA of such expenses (including attorneys&#146; fees), each director and officer receiving such advances, has signed an undertaking to repay to TH USA any amounts advanced to him/her if it shall
ultimately be determined that they are not entitled to be indemnified by TH USA or that the amount advanced to them exceeds the indemnification to which they are entitled as authorized by the By-Laws of TH USA or under applicable law. These amounts
have been expensed and are included in SG&amp;A expenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The
Audit Committee of the Board of Directors reviews transactions between the Company and its affiliates to seek to provide that such transactions are on terms which are no less favorable as a whole to the Company than could be obtained from
unaffiliated parties. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc89342_20"></A>ITEM&nbsp;14. PRINCIPAL ACCOUNTANT FEES AND SERVICES </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:-6px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Set forth below are the (i)&nbsp;audit fees, (ii)&nbsp;audit-related fees, (iii)&nbsp;tax fees, and (iv)&nbsp;all other fees billed to the Company by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (&#147;PwC&#148;), the Company&#146;s
independent auditor, for professional services for the fiscal years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

tax filing and compliance fees of $1,100,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and $792,873 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee&#146;s charter provides that the Audit Committee shall pre-approve all auditing services and permitted non-audit services (including
the fees and terms thereof) to be performed for the Company by its independent auditors, subject to the <I>de minimis</I> exceptions for non-audit services described in Section&nbsp;10A(i)(1)(B) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 which are
approved by the Audit Committee prior to completion of the audit. The Audit Committee may form and delegate authority to subcommittees consisting of one or more members when appropriate, including the authority to grant pre-approvals of audit and
permitted non-audit services, provided that decisions of such subcommittee to grant pre-approvals shall be presented to the full Audit Committee at the next scheduled Audit Committee meeting. In the fiscal year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, 100% of the
audit-related fees, tax fees and all other fees were approved by the Audit Committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee considered whether the provision of non-audit services by PwC is compatible with maintaining PwC&#146;s independence with respect to the Company and determined that to be the case. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
